scenarios: Generated Case 6: [Documentation_Gap] 8yo female with supracondylar fracture from fall off the jungle gym, pink pulseless hand, arrived Saturday 08:00, surgery Saturday 20:00 (12h delay), Borderline.

test_cases.description: Documentation_Gap case testing for 12h delay with pink pulseless hand.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 8-year-old female presented to the emergency department following a fall off a jungle gym. The initial assessment revealed a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture with a pink pulseless hand. The injury occurred on Saturday at approximately 07:00 AM. She arrived at the hospital by 08:00 AM. Neurovascular examination showed no signs of compartment syndrome, and pulse was noted to be absent despite a pink appearance. The surgery was scheduled for Saturday at 08:00 PM, resulting in a significant delay of 12 hours. Discrepancies in the documentation noted that while the initial assessment was thorough, the timing of the neurovascular checks was poorly documented, raising concerns over compliance with standard protocols.

must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department following a fall off a jungle gym
surgery was scheduled for Saturday at 08:00 PM

must_contain_phrases: Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture
arrived at the hospital by 08:00 AM

test_cases.description: Process_Auditor case testing for 10h delay with AIN palsy.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 5-year-old male presented after sustaining a supracondylar humerus fracture during a soccer game. He arrived at the emergency department at 10:00 PM on Friday. Neurovascular assessment showed an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy with inability to perform the 'OK sign.' The surgery was ultimately performed on Saturday at 08:00 AM, resulting in a 10-hour delay to definitive care. The clinical documentation highlighted that while the injury was significant, the urgency of the surgical intervention was not adequately communicated, leading to a clear failure to meet the 18-hour benchmark for time to OR.

must_find_signals: sustaining a supracondylar humerus fracture during a soccer game
surgery was ultimately performed on Saturday at 08:00 AM

must_contain_phrases: arrived at the emergency department at 10:00 PM
clear failure to meet the 18-hour benchmark

test_cases.description: Preventability_Detective case testing for 7.5h delay with pink pulseless hand.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 6-year-old female was brought to the emergency department after falling off the monkey bars, resulting in a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival at 06:30 PM on Friday, she exhibited a pink pulseless hand. The neurovascular assessment indicated no signs of compartment syndrome. However, the surgery was not performed until 02:00 AM the following day, leading to a delay of 7.5 hours. The clinical team noted that the delay was partially due to scheduling conflicts and a lack of available operating room resources, raising questions about preventability of the situation.

surgery was not performed until 02:00 AM

must_contain_phrases: neurovascular assessment indicated no signs of compartment syndrome
questions about preventability of the situation

test_cases.description: Delay_Driver_Profiler case testing for 2.5h delay with normal neurovascular status.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 10-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a horse riding incident, resulting in a Gartland type III supracondylar humerus fracture. His arrival time was recorded at 04:30 PM on Saturday, with a thorough neurovascular examination revealing normal status. The surgery took place at 07:00 PM, resulting in a 2.5-hour delay to surgical intervention. The clinical team indicated that the delay was primarily due to the need for imaging studies and a busy operating room schedule, which were justified given the patientâ€™s stable condition.

test_cases.description: Exclusion_Hunter case testing for 2h delay with pucker sign.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 7-year-old female was brought to the emergency department after a mountain biking accident, resulting in a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture. The assessment noted a significant pucker sign during the physical examination, suggesting potential vascular compromise. Arriving at 05:00 PM on Friday, the surgical intervention commenced at 07:00 PM that evening, reflecting a 2-hour delay. The documentation confirmed that the injury was isolated to the supracondylar region, with no other injuries present, thus qualifying the case for inclusion in the metrics without exclusion.

must_find_signals: resulting in a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture
pucker sign during the physical examination

must_contain_phrases: qualifying the case for inclusion in the metrics without exclusion
